description: Statistics and Probability concepts covering data analysis and chance

definition.text: Descriptive statistics summarize and describe the main features of a dataset. The three measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) tell us about the 'typical' value, while measures of spread (range, variance, standard deviation) describe how spread out the data is.

keyFormulas.name: Mean (Average)
keyFormulas.meaning: Sum of all values divided by count

keyFormulas.name: Median
keyFormulas.formula: Middle value when data is ordered
keyFormulas.meaning: 50th percentile; if n is even, average of two middle values

keyFormulas.name: Range
keyFormulas.meaning: Difference between largest and smallest values

keyFormulas.name: Standard Deviation
keyFormulas.meaning: Square root of variance; same units as data

examples.question: Find the mean, median, and mode of: 4, 7, 2, 9, 4, 5, 4, 8

steps.action: Find median - first order the data

examples.verification: Mode ‚â§ Median ‚â§ Mean (right-skewed data)

examples.question: Find the standard deviation of: 2, 4, 4, 4, 5, 5, 7, 9

steps.action: Take square root for standard deviation

examples.verification: Most values fall within ¬±2 of the mean ‚úì

definition.text: Probability measures the likelihood of an event occurring, expressed as a number between 0 (impossible) and 1 (certain). The probability of an event A is the ratio of favorable outcomes to total possible outcomes in a sample space.

keyFormulas.name: Addition Rule (OR)
keyFormulas.formula: P(A ‚à™ B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A ‚à© B)
keyFormulas.latex: P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)
keyFormulas.meaning: Probability of A or B occurring

keyFormulas.name: Conditional Probability
keyFormulas.meaning: Probability of A given B occurred

examples.question: A die is rolled. Find P(even number) and P(number > 4)
examples.verification: Each outcome equally likely

examples.question: Two coins are tossed. Find P(at least one head)

steps.result:
At least one H = {HH, HT, TH} = 3 outcomes
P = 3/4
P(at least one H) = 1 - P(no H) = 1 - 1/4 = 3/4

examples.verification: Both methods give same answer ‚úì

realWorldApplications.title: Games
realWorldApplications.description: Calculating odds in games of chance

definition.text: Counting principles help determine the number of ways events can occur. Permutations count arrangements where order matters; combinations count selections where order doesn't matter. The factorial n! = n √ó (n-1) √ó ... √ó 2 √ó 1.

keyFormulas.name: Factorial
keyFormulas.meaning: Product of all positive integers up to n; 0! = 1

keyFormulas.name: Permutation
keyFormulas.meaning: Arrangements of r items from n (order matters)

keyFormulas.name: Combination
keyFormulas.meaning: Selections of r items from n (order doesn't matter)

keyFormulas.name: Fundamental Counting Principle
keyFormulas.formula: If event A can occur in m ways and B in n ways, then A followed by B can occur in m √ó n ways

examples.question: How many ways can 3 people be arranged in a line?
examples.verification: ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA - exactly 6

examples.question: How many 5-card hands can be dealt from a standard 52-card deck?

steps.action: This is a combination (order doesn't matter)

examples.verification: This is why poker is interesting!

examples.question: A password has 4 digits (0-9). How many passwords are possible if repetition is allowed?
examples.verification: From 0000 to 9999

definition.text: Data representation involves organizing and displaying data visually through graphs and charts. Common types include bar graphs, histograms, pie charts, line graphs, scatter plots, and box plots. Each type is suited for different kinds of data.

examples.question: In a class, 15 students got A, 20 got B, 10 got C, 5 got D. Find the pie chart angle for grade B.
examples.finalAnswer: Grade B gets 144¬∞ in the pie chart
examples.verification: All angles should sum to 360¬∞

examples.question: Data: 12, 15, 18, 22, 25, 30, 35, 40. Create 4 classes. What is the class width?
examples.verification: 4 classes of width 7 cover the range

definition.text: A probability distribution describes how probabilities are distributed over values of a random variable. Discrete distributions (binomial, Poisson) count outcomes; continuous distributions (normal, exponential) measure quantities. The normal distribution is especially important.

keyFormulas.name: Expected Value
keyFormulas.formula: E[X] = Œ£ x·µ¢P(x·µ¢) or Œº = Œ£x·µ¢/n

keyFormulas.name: Standard Normal (z-score)
keyFormulas.meaning: Number of standard deviations from mean

examples.question: A coin is flipped 5 times. What's the probability of exactly 3 heads?
examples.verification: Most likely outcome for fair coin ‚úì

examples.question: IQ scores have Œº = 100 and œÉ = 15. What percentage score above 130?
examples.verification: z-table gives exactly 2.28%

definition.text: Regression analysis finds the best-fitting line through data points. Linear regression minimizes the sum of squared errors. The resulting equation can predict values and describe the relationship between variables.

keyFormulas.name: Slope
keyFormulas.meaning: Change in y per unit change in x

keyFormulas.name: Coefficient of Determination
keyFormulas.meaning: Proportion of variance explained by model

examples.question: Given regression line ≈∑ = 2.5x + 10, predict y when x = 6
examples.verification: This is an extrapolation if x=6 is in range

examples.question: R¬≤ = 0.85 for a regression model. Interpret this.

steps.result: 85% of the variation in y is explained by the regression on x

examples.finalAnswer: 85% of variation in y is explained by x
examples.verification: High R¬≤ indicates good fit

definition.text: Correlation measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables. The correlation coefficient r ranges from -1 (perfect negative) to +1 (perfect positive). Correlation does not imply causation.

examples.question: Study hours and test scores have r = 0.82. Interpret this.

steps.result: Strong positive linear relationship: more study hours tends to mean higher test scores
steps.explanation: As one increases, so does the other

examples.finalAnswer: Strong positive correlation: more studying associated with higher scores
examples.verification: Does NOT prove studying causes higher scores (correlation ‚â† causation)

examples.question: Ice cream sales and drowning deaths have r = 0.89. Does ice cream cause drowning?

steps.explanation: Hot weather ‚Üí more ice cream AND more swimming

steps.result: No causal relationship; this is spurious correlation

examples.finalAnswer: No! This is a spurious correlation due to confounding variable (temperature)
examples.verification: Classic example of why correlation ‚â† causation

definition.text: The normal (Gaussian) distribution is a bell-shaped probability distribution characterized by mean Œº and standard deviation œÉ. The Empirical Rule states that 68% of data falls within 1œÉ, 95% within 2œÉ, and 99.7% within 3œÉ of the mean.

keyFormulas.name: Z-Score
keyFormulas.meaning: Number of standard deviations from mean

examples.question: SAT scores are normally distributed with Œº = 1000 and œÉ = 200. What percent score above 1400?
examples.verification: Top scorers are rare (above 2œÉ)

examples.question: Heights of women are N(64, 3¬≤) inches. What height is at the 90th percentile?
examples.verification: 90% of women are shorter than this

definition.text: Hypothesis testing is a statistical method to make decisions about populations based on sample data. We start with a null hypothesis (H‚ÇÄ) and determine if there's enough evidence to reject it in favor of an alternative hypothesis (H‚ÇÅ).

examples.question: A company claims 80% satisfaction. A survey of 200 shows 148 satisfied. Test at Œ± = 0.05.

steps.explanation: Testing if satisfaction differs from claim

examples.finalAnswer: Reject H‚ÇÄ. Evidence suggests satisfaction differs from 80%
examples.verification: Sample shows significantly lower satisfaction

definition.text: A confidence interval is a range of values that likely contains the true population parameter. A 95% CI means if we repeated sampling many times, 95% of intervals would contain the true value. The margin of error depends on confidence level, sample size, and variability.

examples.question: A sample of 100 students has mean GPA 3.2, s = 0.5. Find 95% CI for true mean.
examples.verification: We're 95% confident true mean GPA is between 3.10 and 3.30

realWorldApplications.title: Polling
realWorldApplications.description: Election results with margin of error

definition.text: Sampling methods are techniques for selecting individuals from a population for study. Good sampling reduces bias and allows valid inferences. Simple random sampling gives every member equal chance; stratified sampling divides into groups first.

examples.question: How large a sample is needed for 95% CI with margin of error 3% on a proportion?
examples.verification: Larger sample = smaller margin of error

definition.text: Box plots (box-and-whisker) display the five-number summary: min, Q‚ÇÅ, median, Q‚ÇÉ, max. They show data spread, center, and identify outliers. Quartiles divide sorted data into four equal parts.

keyFormulas.name: Outlier Rule
keyFormulas.formula: Outlier if x < Q‚ÇÅ - 1.5√óIQR or x > Q‚ÇÉ + 1.5√óIQR

examples.question: Data: 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 12, 15. Find five-number summary.

definition.text: Linear regression finds the best-fitting straight line through a set of data points. It minimizes the sum of squared residuals. The equation ≈∑ = a + bx predicts y-values from x-values.

keyFormulas.name: Coefficient of Determination
keyFormulas.meaning: Proportion of variance explained by model

examples.question: Given: xÃÑ = 5, »≥ = 12, s‚Çì = 2, s·µß = 6, r = 0.8. Find regression equation.
examples.verification: At x = 5, ≈∑ = 12 (passes through means) ‚úì

examples.question: Using ≈∑ = 3 + 2x, what is the predicted y when x = 10? What's the residual if actual y = 24?
examples.verification: Positive residual means actual > predicted

definition.text: Chi-square tests assess relationships between categorical variables. The goodness-of-fit test checks if observed frequencies match expected frequencies. The independence test checks if two categorical variables are related.

examples.question: Die rolled 60 times: 1s=12, 2s=8, 3s=10, 4s=9, 5s=11, 6s=10. Is it fair?

steps.action: Find df and compare to critical value

examples.finalAnswer: œá¬≤ = 1.0, do not reject H‚ÇÄ. Die appears fair.
examples.verification: Low œá¬≤ means good fit to expected

definition.text: T-tests compare means when population standard deviation is unknown. The one-sample t-test compares a sample mean to a hypothesized value. The two-sample t-test compares means of two groups.

examples.question: Sample: n=25, xÃÑ=82, s=10. Test if Œº = 80 at Œ± = 0.05.
examples.finalAnswer: t = 1.0, fail to reject H‚ÇÄ. No significant difference from 80.
examples.verification: p-value > 0.05

definition.text: ANOVA tests whether the means of three or more groups are equal. It compares variance between groups to variance within groups. A significant F-ratio suggests at least one group mean differs.

keyFormulas.name: F-Statistic
keyFormulas.meaning: Ratio of between to within variance

keyFormulas.name: Degrees of Freedom
keyFormulas.meaning: k = number of groups, N = total observations

examples.question: Three groups with means 10, 15, 20 and overall mean 15. Each n=10, MSW=25. Is there a difference?
examples.finalAnswer: F = 10, reject H‚ÇÄ. Groups have significantly different means.
examples.verification: Large F indicates large between-group variation

realWorldApplications.title: Agriculture
realWorldApplications.description: Comparing crop yields with different fertilizers

definition.text: The Pearson correlation coefficient (r) measures the strength and direction of the linear relationship between two variables. It ranges from -1 (perfect negative) to +1 (perfect positive), with 0 indicating no linear relationship.

examples.question: Z‚Çì scores: -1.5, -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1.5. Z·µß scores: -1, -1, 0, 0.5, 1.5. Find r.
examples.verification: Close to 1, strong positive linear relationship

definition.text: The binomial distribution models the number of successes in n independent trials, each with probability p of success. It's discrete and symmetric when p = 0.5.

examples.question: Flip a fair coin 10 times. What's P(exactly 6 heads)?
examples.verification: Mean = 5, so 6 is slightly above average
